text:
47-40 Washington Square South, west from Sullivan to Macdougal Streets. These houses will be drastically remodeled about 1923. At the time of this picture Sullivan Street had only recently been cut through the block from West Third Street, thus causing the demolition for 48-49 Washington Square. 49 Washington Square had been the Westmore Home for Fallen and Friendless Girls (established 1881).

Notice the old horse-car track alongside the more modern electric track.

September 8, 1905.

Brown Brothers, Photographers.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - Sullivan Street

text:
47-40 Washington Square South, west from Sullivan to Macdougal Streets.
Compare with Brown Brothers' photo of this block in 1905, a year or two after Sullivan Street had been cut through from West Third Street. As shown here, the buildings are shortly to be remodelled into apartments and studios.
About 1922.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.
title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - Sullivan Street

text:
(1) Washington Square, from Sullivan Street, is indeed the perfect setting, for just such as the semi-annual Art Exhibit.

November 13, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) Same.

May 27, 1935.

P. L. Sperr,
title: Artists and poets - Greenwich Village.

text:
Enterprising vendor, attends the second outdoor Art Exhibit at 247 Sullivan Street, in the hope that people would buy his hot potatoes to keep warm.

November 17, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Artists and poets - Greenwich Village.
